After clocking in around 600 hours, heres my verdict:

Consider yourself as a person who don't really expect much, just to catch a glimpse of  being an NBA superstar. Getting drafted, getting to the league, playing alongside your favorite superstars, breaking records, etc etc (not fucking Instagram super models tho). The game is decent, if these are your requirements in finding happiness while playing your favorite sports, digitally.

But if you're into the competitive PvP modes and not missing out important features, this aint it. Being "Current Gen" really messes up the overall experience. Not to mention online PvP modes come with delayed shot timing due to the server problems they will never rectify. Oh and, if you're not willing to put in some grindz, the micro-transactions are your choice, but they made it in such a way that really fucks up the game. 

For me, I find this game enjoyable. Because I don't play PvP, just for the pure MyCareer experience. No in-game transactions, nothing. But one thing is for sure tho, I really hoped that they made MyCareer offline, so I could really play it for a really long time. But the developers wouldn't listen anyways, and the minimal effort is proven of incredible amount of things that can be improved that can be determined by a dude without any creativity, just like me.

I would like to say its a very bad game from multiple aspects.
First and foremost, the shooting mechanics feel like a step backward rather than an improvement. The developers claim to have introduced a more realistic approach, but what we got is a convoluted mess. Timing is everything, they say, but in practice, it's more like a guessing game. The inconsistency in shot success is baffling, with seemingly identical releases yielding drastically different results. This unpredictability undermines the skill-based aspect of the game, leaving players feeling helpless and robbed of agency.

The players' basketball IQ, or lack thereof, is another glaring issue. It's disheartening to witness AI-controlled teammates making baffling decisions that defy the fundamentals of the sport. Whether it's a lack of spatial awareness, questionable shot selection, or failing to recognize open teammates, the overall basketball IQ of the players is abysmal. This not only ruins the immersion but also makes it nearly impossible to execute strategic plays or enjoy a cohesive team experience.

Moreover, the supposed improvements in player animations and realism are overshadowed by the glaring flaws in the game's core mechanics. Clunky movements, awkward transitions, and unrealistic player reactions further contribute to the overall disappointment. It's as if the developers sacrificed fundamental gameplay for the sake of flashy graphics, leaving players with a visually appealing but fundamentally flawed gaming experience.

In conclusion, NBA 2K23 is a regrettable step backward for the franchise. The shooting system's unpredictability and the abysmal basketball IQ of players make for a frustrating and unrewarding gaming experience. Until these issues are addressed and the core gameplay is refined, it's hard to recommend this installment to anyone who values a true-to-life and enjoyable basketball simulation. Save your money and stick to earlier, more polished entries in the NBA 2K series.

So, I'll start by saying, I enjoy the game. Roughly 112 hours in it proves it. However, I can't recommend a title in this price range that's as buggy as it is. My system isn't top shelf, but it's no slouch either. I know how to tweak my settings appropriately. Still, this game is going to crash. Unfortunately, such a crash happened roughly 14hrs prior to this review. In the playoffs, just after finishing a 2nd match-up against The Raptors.  Won the first, lost the 2nd by 3. After the game, a message from Gatorade directed me to the purser's desk to collect my payment for an event. While I was loading into the neighborhood, the game crashes. Now, I can't load into MyCareer. I have a pretty extensive troubleshooting background. I didn't just give up. I dug deep. Tried all the cloud manipulating tricks I know short of deleting everything and starting over. Deleted and reloaded local files. Un/reinstalled the game. Nothing. Just borked. Even trying to load a game in MyTeam malfunctions now. The only hope I have at this point is that an upcoming season brings a patch to untie whatever garbage tech knot has been tied. Every other title I own is operating just fine. I fear that even if a patch does correct the issue, I will have to surrender whatever career progress I made and start again. I'm confident that my character build is still intact. So at least there is that. I really wish that bigger titles like this did more to release a functioning product they can maintain versus meeting some weak, predetermined release date. If you're gonna buy the game, wait for a good sale. Keep your backups up to date. And, simply understand, even though it has been tightened up mechanically. This is still another fickle 2k title just like any other.

This game gets a 2/10 for the PC version.

To start with the obvious issues and downsides based on the actual game itself: 

- The game is capped at 60 FPS in multiplayer 
- The game has the absolute worst input lag of any multiplayer game you will ever touch; it feels like at least 100 MS lag.
- The game is stuck in old gen, so PC players with even decent PC builds aren't allowed to play the best version of 2K
- The Game is pay to-win; either you grind for 300+ hours for VC or pay $100 and build your player or MyTeam
- The Game will randomly crash every so often or lose connection because it's not made for PC
- Game is filled with cheaters, and I mean FILLED
- MyTeam is nothing but money-hungry overpriced packs filled with 99 overall players.

Now here are some upsides and the reason I Played/Play it:

- Offline mode My League is solid; you can run your own league run simulations (for the nerds) and customize a lot
- The game receives player overall updates every 2 weeks up until playoffs and will continue to in 2K24
- The game-play itself can be fun in offline mode but is pretty mid online
- If playing online, don't expect anything close to realism with how the basketball is played. It's just constant dribble spam.
- Fun to bring friends over and play offline 1 on 1 or 5 on 5.

I hopped on 2k23 late in the game, so this review is with the context of not having to deal with any launch issues, first season bugs, or exploits / toxicity in the early, more populated community.

Pros:
-Good graphics and animations.
-Fun online play with friends.
-Lots of customization options for your MyPlayer.
-A pretty solid story line for the MyCareer.
-MyGM and MyLeague are still incredibly fun, especially with the retro rosters. 

Cons:
-Monotony sets in fast in the game play loop.
-The good animations sometimes bug out and look stoppy and awkward.
-Keyboard smashing Hall of Fame difficulty.
-The crowds are still cardboard and the announcers usually aren't even talking about whats actually happening.
-Random performance dips that happen without any rhyme or reason.
-Can you even make 3 pointers without a 99 3pt shot?

**Lots of TL/DR below.**

The last 2K game that I played was 2k18 and I'd played almost all of them since 2k13, with a pause between when the originals were first coming out. Immediately, I was impressed by this game and that's probably just because it was the first one I'd picked up in years. For people who play this game every year, it makes sense how they'd be frustrated with only small changes but if you're gonna pick this game up on sale (which I did and recommend) then it is absolutely night and day. Graphics, animations, features, and the feel of the game on both keyboard and controller has absolutely evolved. 

There are some big problems though with 2k23 and most of it stems from progression in this game. Having your progression constantly stall out while you grind points till your next overall is a feature I'm pretty sure isn't new, but it really does add to the monotony of playing an 82 game season especially when you play it on Hall of Fame where every single game is a DRAG to complete with how insane the cheese from the CPU and computer is. Missing wide open layups with a 95 overall slashing forward is INSANITY. This creates a really frustrating and daunting game play loop of watching your bars and badges progress climb barely a millimetre and as someone who didn't immediately grind this game in 2022, I'm unfortunately going to have to restart this entire process over for 2k24 which I will be purchasing on launch because I'm excited to see if they'll repair some of the shortcomings of this franchise.

Or you can of course "pay to win", but it's not stopping you from doing anything other than helping you make your player decked out on day 1 as opposed to progressing through the game for a month or so.  
There is nothing in this game you can strictly buy to be better than other players that you can not earn through natural progression in about 30 - 60 days of just playing your rookie year for your MyPlayer.

The complaining aside about VC cash transactions, this game is great.  As always, it plays very well and is an awesome representation of the NBA game.  The My Career is rather unchanged from years prior save a few tweeks, which IMO is good as it's fun and the *cough* more you play, the easier it becomes to get free VC (at about the allstar break, pending how good you are at the game, you can earn VC hand over fist to the point buying it would be pointless anyway).   

So for those worried about all the moaning about "needing to" buy VC, this is coming from players who want their character to be Prime Michael Jordan on day one, probably too lazy to just play the game and earn it, which does not take all that long. Playing 1 full rookie season will give you about the same, if not more VC, than the $50 package. 

Save your extra money, play the game, get better at it and progress over time, and just have fun working your way up the ranks.  You can't win them all anyway, why try to pay extra for that?

Despite my long hours totaled. This game is only recommended for people who are addicted to sports games. NBA 2k is not a inherently terrible product. There is reason why so many people, myself included, log long hours in these games. It is miles better than say a Madden but I cannot recommend NBA 2K23 for five major reasons:

1) PC Version of 2K is on an outdated engine compared to PS5 and Xbox versions. PS5 version include options like bounce pass alley oops as well as a new Mycareer area.

2) Mycareer is one of the longest and most useless grinds in all of gaming. To play 2K without spending VC is borderline impossible. I am not doing it since I normally play end of year but if you seriously wanted to try out 4-5 different myplayer builds then you probably are going to spend hundred of hours and dollars on this cashcow. On top of this, the servers exist for only 2 years after each title's release.
  
3) MyCareer AI is really awful. Star players for your roster will repeatedly miss wide open three pointers and mid range shots. Opponent AI is surprisingly easy compared to year's past to a fault. There are three solutions for better teammate AI but they all have their faults. The first is to increase your player's Dimer and Floor General Badges. This will eventually make your team function normally but can take some time and your player may not even have these badges. The second is to simply run more plays. This will create more ball movement as well as allow your player to go offball but the AI simply cannot function on their own without the previously mentioned Floor General Badge. The third option is to decrease difficulty which turns your opponents into helpless children and your entire team into nuclear Klay Thompson shooters which is also non-simulation like. I tend to run a fair bit of AI vs AI games to watch how player tendencies work and such and the AI moves the ball too slowly. I cannot explain it well but there just needs to be more in general driving/kicking/shooting rather than everyone standing around for half of the possession.

4) FIX THE ONLINE SERVERS. Good grief, my player is finally freaking good enough for the rec center and I am battling the 2K servers more than the opponents. Rec Center log in issues have been existent for almost a decade at this point. 

5) Haven't played much of it but the Gm and Franchise modes seem lackluster and repetitive of year's past as well.

My rant is over. 2K is deep and immersive when it is working but often stumbles over itself. I haven't even really discussed the inherent VC greed that exists. I would love for this game to really focus on fixing their grind and servers. I normally buy this game during the 10 dollar sale which makes me more open to buying VC than I ever would but with how poorly the servers are I ain't spending another cent on 2k. The only time this game is justifiable to buy is when it is 10 dollars.

NBA 2K23 became the catalyst for my undoing, a relentless force that stole my dreams, crushed my spirit, and left me a mere husk of a person. Its grip on my soul tightened with every passing day until hope was extinguished, leaving only a desolate wasteland of despair.

Hi, I'm a 2k Franchise fanatic, and I have been for quite some time between many different consoles to now PC in the last year or so. The franchise as a whole, in specifically NBA 2k, has really targeted an niche audience of whom I only assume are either kids mooching off their parent's credit card OR the percent of adults who are able to sit at home all day, every-day and are doomed/convinced to spend every last penny to find a way to enjoy this game any longer.

It's no secret that there are modders/hackers who are flooding the Park with their squad to ruin everyone else's day, but I personally don't feel the need to comment on that as you can all read below. MyTeam is a pay-to-win fantasy mode where you'll "build" a team of shit-tier today players against people with super-teams consisting of cards you haven't even seen before. 

Ninety percent of my playtime was spent in the MyCareer game mode. This mode has been underwhelming for years, but the development team has thrown all their effort out of the window as far as a basis career story-line. Personally, I am not even passed the All-Star break, and I don't get a lick of post-game interview options or scenes anymore? They were already short-written and horribly voiced anyway, but I don't even get that anymore? The endorsements, the player interaction, the character development..- all of it just written while sitting on a toiler the morning after Taco Bell. 

There's no reward for trying to stick through the grind and actually play this game. I'm a 95 overall with more common build you'd find on your first search on the internet. I've grinded out all my badge upgrades to the point where I am literally playing every season game for a grand reward of MAYBE 1500 VC on Superstar difficulty? An upgrade costs 3-5000 VC per upgrade?! The difficulty scaling can be dumbed down this: get minuscule amounts of "more" VC for the FEWER shots made due to the bots OR score more for enjoyment and get paid sh** tier.

This morning's few hour session really put a damper on my gaming today, so I'm just giving up on the franchise as a whole. I don't care about 2K24, so stop trying to shove that down my throat if you can find a way to do that. I shouldn't have bought the game when I found out the developers port their PC version as "old-generation". I loathe for the day Ronnie2k and the team as a whole go bankrupt.

Title: A Revolutionary Leap: NBA 2K23 on PC - A Review

Ladies and gentlemen, I stand in awe of the technological marvels that grace this world, and among them is NBA 2K23 on PC. This basketball simulation opus has taken a considerable leap forward in its latest installment. As a seasoned player and observer of the sport, I present my review of this virtual spectacle.

NBA 2K23 on PC presents a visual feast, unrivaled in its realism and attention to detail. The meticulously rendered player models, with their fluid animations and lifelike expressions, transport one onto the virtual hardwood. The lighting effects and faithfully recreated arenas create an immersive atmosphere that rivals the grandest of real-life arenas.

The game's enhanced AI and strategic depth provide players with an experience akin to coaching a real-life team. The improved player intelligence allows for more realistic decision-making, both on and off the ball. Whether executing precise pick-and-rolls or devising complex defensive strategies, NBA 2K23 captures the essence of basketball's tactical nuances.

The beloved MyCareer mode continues to shine, offering an engrossing narrative-driven experience. The depth of character customization, the journey from humble beginnings to stardom, and the sense of camaraderie with virtual teammates make for a compelling and memorable career. This mode truly allows players to live out their hoop dreams.

Alas, NBA 2K23 suffers from the bane of modern gaming: microtransactions. While understanding the need for developers to generate revenue, the overwhelming prominence of these microtransactions can hinder the overall enjoyment of the game. Some aspects, such as player upgrades or cosmetics, become locked behind paywalls, disrupting the balance between skill and monetary investment.

As with any game heavily reliant on online connectivity, NBA 2K23 struggles to maintain a consistent online experience at times. Server issues, latency, and occasional disconnections can mar an otherwise enjoyable gameplay session. It is my fervent hope that the developers address these concerns swiftly to provide a more reliable online experience for all.

In the realm of virtual basketball, NBA 2K23 on PC stands as a monumental achievement, offering a breathtaking visual experience and unparalleled tactical depth. The MyCareer mode captivates players, providing a narrative-rich journey of basketball stardom. Nevertheless, the presence of pervasive microtransactions and occasional online stability issues warrant consideration. Despite these imperfections, NBA 2K23 remains a game of choice for those seeking an immersive basketball simulation, deserving of praise and further refinement.

Disappointing and Underwhelming Experience

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

As an avid fan of the NBA 2K series, it pains me to say that NBA 2K23 falls short of expectations. The game promises to offer an immersive basketball experience, but it ultimately fails to deliver on multiple fronts.

Let's start with the MyCAREER mode, which has always been a highlight of the series. Unfortunately, in NBA 2K23, the storyline feels uninspired and lacks the engaging narrative we've come to expect. The character development is shallow, and the interactions with other players and coaches feel repetitive and devoid of depth. It's disheartening to see such a lackluster effort in a mode that should be the game's centerpiece.

Moving on to MyTEAM, which boasts the exciting concept of pairing All-Stars with legendary players. While the idea sounds great in theory, the execution falls flat. The gameplay balance is severely skewed, with overpowered cards dominating the competition. This not only diminishes the sense of strategy and skill but also creates a pay-to-win environment where those who invest more money have a significant advantage. It's a disappointment for those who were hoping for fair competition and a level playing field.

The MyGM and MyLEAGUE modes, which are usually rich in customization and managerial depth, feel remarkably neglected in NBA 2K23. The lack of meaningful updates and improvements leaves players with a stale and repetitive experience. The potential for creating a captivating dynasty or steering the NBA in a new direction feels squandered, leaving players with a sense of wasted potential.

While the promise of true-to-life gameplay is mentioned in the game's description, it fails to live up to its claim. The AI frequently exhibits questionable decision-making, resulting in frustrating moments during matches. The animations lack fluidity, and the player movement feels clunky and unresponsive at times. These issues significantly hinder the overall immersion and enjoyment of the game.

In conclusion, NBA 2K23 is a disappointing installment in the series. It fails to live up to its predecessors and struggles to offer a compelling basketball experience. Lackluster storytelling, unbalanced gameplay, and neglected game modes all contribute to an overall sense of mediocrity. While the visuals and presentation are commendable, they alone cannot salvage the game. It's a regrettable misstep that leaves fans yearning for the excellence that the series was once known for.
